concept.title: Avoiding special characters in file names
concept.shortdesc: Special characters must not be used in file names.

conbody.p: Using special characters in file names may cause some problems or errors in some authoring and publishing tools. Special characters in this context means symbols, typographical characters, punctuation characters, spaces, diacritical characters, and non-Latin characters.
You must treat file names as though they are URIs, and follow the IETF syntax conventions for URI naming.
Refer to IETF Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax for the comprehensive URI guidelines.

section.title: Observations
section.p: This is an example of where an inline xref is appropriate, as it is central to the topic message. The topic won't stand alone without the link; therefore, it should not be conditional in any way (and thus shouldn't be created as a reltable link). It may be able to be incorporated within a related-links structure after the topic body, but semantically it is not a related link, but an integral link.

section.title: Rationale
section.lq: I totally agree with this, but I think that it can be said stronger - that in fact all such file names in DITA are URIs, and thus must follow the standards for URI naming. I know that you can use a space in a file name and get away with it in for example the DOT, but that is a bug in the tools; the tools should validate that all "file names" (such as in <topicref href="file-name-which-is-actually-a-URI.dita" type="task">) are legal URIs and thus fail the build when for example a space is used in the file name. I am not 100% sure about this, but I think I remember Eliot writing something about this on the DITA mailing list, but cannot find the piece right now.
